title: Funding Frictions after the Global Financial Crisis
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Funding Frictions after the Global Financial Crisis," aims to investigate the impact of funding frictions on financing conditions for countries, banks, pension plans, and life insurance companies in the aftermath of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the March 2020 Covid-19 market turmoil. The key focus areas include understanding funding frictions, optimizing policy responses, and reducing funding risks for institutions. The project will examine manifestations of these frictions such as elevated external financing costs, shorter debt maturities, and lack of credit market access.

By studying market changes such as ballooning deficits in developed economies, tighter regulations on Money Market Mutual funds, pension risk transfers to life insurance companies, and Basel III regulations on banks, the project aims to answer research questions on the effect of market developments on funding frictions. The expected outcomes include insights on funding costs and credit market access, debt management strategies for sovereigns, and increased policy maker awareness of regulatory consequences.

This research is crucial for informing policy decisions to mitigate funding frictions and improve financing conditions for the entities involved. By addressing these issues, the project seeks to contribute to the stability and resilience of the financial system post-global financial crises.

The proposed project, "Funding Frictions after the Global Financial Crisis," aims to investigate the impact of funding frictions on financing conditions for various entities post-GFC. The project will focus on understanding funding frictions, optimizing policy responses, and reducing funding risks for countries, banks, pension funds, and insurance companies. By examining manifestations of frictions such as elevated external financing costs and lack of credit market access, the research will address key questions regarding market developments post-GFC.

Significant events like the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the March 2020 Covid-19 market turmoil will provide a backdrop for the study, with market changes examined including ballooning deficits in developed economies and tighter regulations on Money Market Mutual funds and banks (Basel III). The project aims to generate insights on funding costs, credit market access, and debt management strategies for sovereigns, ultimately increasing policy maker awareness of regulatory consequences.

The expected outcomes of this research include a better understanding of how funding frictions impact financing conditions post-GFC, as well as recommendations for reducing funding risks for affected entities. By shedding light on these critical issues, the project seeks to inform policy makers and institutions on strategies to navigate funding frictions in a post-crisis environment.
